contentrichtext.text: [[File:Schema Orloj pragueorlojhzenilc.jpg|thumb|Dial of Prague Astronomical Clock made according to Jan Šindel's research in 1410.]] '''Jan Šindel''' (1370s – between 1455 and 1457),<ref name=orloj></ref> also known as '''Jan Ondřejův''' ({{Lang-la| Iohannes Andreae dictus Schindel}} or ''Joannes de Praga'') was a [[Czechs|Czech]] medieval [[scientist]] and [[Catholic priest]]. He was a professor at [[Charles University]] in [[Prague]] and became the [[Rector (academia)|rector]] of the University in 1410. He lectured on [[mathematics]] and [[astronomy]] and was also a personal astrologer and physician of kings [[Wenceslaus IV of Bohemia]] and his brother [[Holy Roman Emperor]] [[Sigismund, Holy Roman Emperor|Sigismund]].<ref name=orloj></ref> == Life == Jan Šindel was born in the Bohemian town [[Hradec Králové]] probably in the 1370s. A a young man he came to Prague to study at the Charles University. In 1395 or 1399<ref name=orloj></ref> he became the Master of Arts at the Prague University. In 1406 he worked at the parish school of the [[St. Nicholas Church (Malá Strana)|St. Nicolas Church]] in the [[Malá Strana|Lesser Town of Prague]]. Later he worked as a teacher of mathematics in [[Vienna]], where he also studied medicine. Then he came back to Prague and became the professor of astronomy at the Charles University, there he became Doctor of Medicine and rector of the University in 1410. At the beginning he was a supporter of [[John Hus]] but later he stayed [[Catholic Church|Catholic]]. He avoided religious disputes and preferred science.<ref name=clock></ref> In 1418 he became a [[Canon (priest)|canon]] of Prague [[St. Vitus Cathedral|St. Vitus]] [[Chapter (religion)|Chapter]]. Because of the [[Hussite Wars]] he had to leave Prague and came to [[Olomouc]]. In 1423-1436 he worked in [[Nuremberg]] as a physician. In 1432 he became the personal physician of the Emperor Sigismund. In 1441 he became the [[Dean (Christianity)|dean]] of the [[Vyšehrad]] Chapter in Prague. He had a good relationship to [[Enea Silvio Bartolomeo Piccolomini]] (later [[pope]] Pius II), their correspondence from the years 1445-1447 has been preserved. He died probably between 1455 and 1457 in Prague.<ref name=orloj>{{cite web|title=Jan Šindel|url=http://www.orloj.eu/cs/sindel.htm#3|work=Prague Orloj website|accessdate=23 June 2013|language=Czech}}</ref> ==Legacy== Šindel's astronomical tables and maps were allegedly still used by [[Tycho Brahe]]. He had a special liking for astronomical devices. Based on his suggestion and calculations [[Mikuláš of Kadaň]] constructed the [[Prague Orloj]] clock in 1410.<ref name=orloj></ref> In 1982, an asteroid ([[3847 Šindel]]) was named after him.<ref name=clock>{{cite web|title=Personalities related to the Prague Astronomical Clock|url=http://www.orloj.eu/en/orloj_osobnosti.htm|work=Prague Orloj website|accessdate=23 June 2013|language=English}}</ref> ==Reference== <references/> {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Sindel, Jan | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Czech astronomer | DATE OF BIRTH = 1370 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1443 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sindel, Jan}} [[Category:1370 births]] [[Category:1443 deaths]] [[Category:Czech astronomers]] {{CzechRepublic-scientist-stub}} {{Europe-astronomer-stub}}
